description.en:
The course is introductory, specialist terms are largely avoided, focusing instead on several well-studied biological systems that concisely demonstrate key principles. 
The course will present an integrated approach in which the quantitative experimental data from biochemical and cell biology research is used to create predictive models of cellular systems. Examples will be discussed to demonstrate how cell-level functions arise and why mechanistic knowledge of the biochemical systems allows us to predict behaviors leading to different cell fate decisions, and also to disease states and drug responses.
description.et: Tegemist on sissejuhatava kursusega, eritermineid püütakse vältida, keskendutakse põhiliselt läbiuuritud bioloogiliste süsteemide abil võtmeprintsiipide demonstreerimisele. Kursus pakub integreeritud lähenemist kasutades reaalseid kvantitatiivseid eksperimditulemusi rakusüsteemide ennustuslike mudelite loomisel. Tuuakse palju näiteid rakuliste funktsioonide kujunemisest ja õpetatakse kuidas biokeemiliste süsteemide mehhanismi tasemel mõistmine aitab ennustada rakulisi otsustusprotsesse, haigusolekuid ja ravimimõjusid.

objectives.en: The course builds a solid foundation for the intuitive understanding of general principles of biological systems. It encourages the students to ask why a system is designed in a particular way and then proceeds to answer with simplified models.
objectives.et: Kursus laob kindla alusmüüri biomolekulaarsete süsteemide üldprintsiipide mõistmiseks. Üliõpilasi õhutatakse mõtlema miks on süsteemid arenenud justnimelt sellisteks nagu me neid näeme. Samuti õpetatakse looma süsteeme kirjeldavaid lihtsustatud mudeleid.

learning_outcomes.en: Recent advances in technology have revolutionized biology enabling the collection of large sets of genomics, metabolomics and proteomics data. The new discipline of systems biology aims to meet the most important challenge of the 'post-omics' era: to understand the mechanisms of the biomolecular networks. The course presents the design principles of biological systems, and highlights the recurring circuit elements that make up biolomolecular networks. It provides a simple mathematical framework which can be used to understand and even design biological circuits.
learning_outcomes.et: Viimase aja tehnoloogilised arengud on toonud bioloogiasse revoltutsioonilisi muutusi, mida ilmestab suur hulk kogutud genoomi, metaboloomi ja proteoomi andmeid. Uus teadusharu, mida kutsutakse süsteemibioloogiaks püüab lahendada ühte suurimat "pos-genoomse" ajajärgu väljakutset: mõista biomolekulaarsete süsteemide mehhanisme. Kursus pakub ülevaate bioloogiliste süsteemide disainiprintsiipidest ja moodulitest, mis moodustavad biomolakulaarseid signaalivõrgustikke. Kursus pakub lihtsa matemaatilise lähenemistasandi, mille abil saab mõista ja disainida bioloogilisi võrgustikke.

description.et: Definition of systems biology.Molecular networks of the cell. Network architecture and network motifs of biomolecular systems. Network companents. network measures. Erdos and Rényi random network model (ER). Random ER vs Scale-Free Networks. Evolution of the scale-free networks: preferential attachment/ rich-get-richer principle. Error and attack tolerance of complex networks. Network fragmentation under random failures and attacks.

Basic concept of transcriptional networks. Basic elements and regulatory mechanisms of transcriptional networks. Transcriptional activators and repressors. Concept of separation of timescales. Modeling transcriptional regulation: Hill function and logic step function. Dynamics and response time of simple gene regulation. Negative and positive autoregulation.
MATLAB modeling practice. ODE simulations of transcriptional circuits introduced in lectures 1-2.

Transcription networks. Three-node network motifs. Feed-forward loops. Coherent and incoherent type feed-forward loops, their dynamic behavior and emergent properties. The coherent type 1 FFL as a sign sensitive delay element and persistence detector. The incoherent type-1 FFL as pulse generator and sign-sensitive accelerator. Temporal programs and global structure of the transcription networks.
MATLAB modeling practice. ODE simulations of transcriptional circuits introduced in lecture 3.

The single input module (SIM) network motif. SIM with last-in-first out or LIFO order. Temporal order in arginine biosynthesis system. Ordered transcription of cell cycle genes at G1/S transition combined with feedback loops. Simple topological generalizations of the FFLs. Multi-output FFL that regulates the flagella motor genes. First-in-First-out  order (FIFO) in the multi-Z FFL with OR-logic input functions. The transcription network guiding development of the B. subtilis spore. A generalized repressilator model. Signal Integration and Combinatorial Control: Bi-Fans and Dense Overlapping  regulons. The 4- and 5-node network motifs in sensory transcription networks. The global structure of the E. coli transcription network.
MATLAB modeling practice. ODE simulations of functional modules introduced in lecture 4.

Positive transcriptional feedback loops with two nodes. The regulated-feedback network motifs in developmental transcription networks. Transcription cascades. Motifs in protein signal transduction networks. Post-translational modification of protein. Protein kinase-phosphatase switches. Multisite phosphorylation of protein. Protein kinase cascades. Network motifs in signal- transduction networks.
MATLAB modeling practice. ODE simulations of functional modules introduced in lecture 5.

Signaling motifs and signaling modules. Ultrasensitive and graded signal responces. Goldbeter-Koshland zero-order ultrasensitive switch. Kinase-phosphatase signal-response modules.Ultrasensitive signal response in kinase cascades.
MATLAB modeling practice. ODE simulations and analysis of parametre space for the oscillatory systems introduced in lecture 5.
Homework 1 consultation

Signal response modules: perfectly adapted, mutual activation, mutual inhibition, negative feedback homeostasis. One-way switch, the toggle switch. A positive-feedback-based bistable 'memory module' in oocyte maturation.
MATLAB modeling practice. ODE simulations and analysis of parametre space for the oscillatory systems introduced in lecture 7.
MATLAB modeling practice. ODE simulations and analysis of parametre space for the oscillatory systems introduced in lecture 7.

Oscillating circuits: cell division cycle oscillator. Minimal APC-CDK oscillator. Combination of a negative feedback loop with a positive feedback loop: the core oscillating module of the cell cycle. From a hysteretic switch to a relaxation oscillator. Hierarchy of the systems biology models. Boolean model of the cell cycle.
MATLAB modeling practice. ODE simulations and analysis of parametre space for the oscillatory systems introduced in lecture 8.
Kinetic proofreading and conformational proofreading.
Homework 2 consultation
Seminar and consultation introducing the topics for the exam.
